nodes.text: A likelihood-based vector autoregressive model with cointegration (parameterized by alpha and beta) provides a coherent statistical framework to describe nonstationary multivariate time series, test cointegration relations, estimate parameters, and interpret long-run and short-run dynamics

Definition: A p-dimensional process x_t is I(1) if differences are a linear process with nonzero cumulative coefficient C(1); x_t is cointegrated if there exists nonzero beta such that beta' x_t is stationary; the cointegration rank is the number of independent cointegrating vectors

Three parametric model formulations describe cointegration: regression residual-based formulation (Engle-Granger), autoregressive error-correction formulation Delta x_t = alpha beta' x_{t-1} + errors, and unobserved components formulation linking cointegration to common stochastic trends

Granger Representation Theorem: under the I(1) condition (unit roots only at z=1 and rank condition |alpha_perp' Gamma beta_perp| != 0), the VAR error-correction model has representation with p - r common stochastic trends and r stationary long-run relations; C = beta_perp (alpha_perp' Gamma beta_perp)^{-1} alpha_perp'

Interpretation: Cointegrating coefficients beta represent long-run relations; coefficients alpha measure short-run adjustment towards attractor set {x: beta' x = 0}; a change in long-run value k that satisfies beta' k = 0 can be realized by altering current x_t by C Gamma k

Method: The paper analyzes the VAR I(1) model Delta x_t = alpha(beta' x_{t-1} + Upsilon D_t) + sum Gamma_i Delta x_{t-i} + Phi d_t + epsilon_t with deterministic terms and i.i.d. errors and describes parameter roles and identifiability issues for alpha, beta and common trends

Result: Deterministic terms d_t can produce cumulated trends via C Phi but Dt enters orthogonally (C alpha Upsilon = 0), so inclusion or exclusion of linear trend terms changes asymptotic behavior of tests and representation of long-run means

Method: Likelihood-based estimation of the VAR cointegration model is obtained via reduced rank regression (RRR) and Gaussian maximum likelihood; RRR solves eigenvalue problem for residual covariances and yields estimates of beta, alpha, Gamma and Omega

Result: The likelihood ratio test for cointegration rank r versus p is computed from eigenvalues lambda_i as -2 log LR = -T sum_{i=r+1}^p log(1 - lambda_i); models H(r) are nested and can be compared by this LR statistic

Asymptotic Evidence: The asymptotic distribution of the rank test depends on deterministic terms and number of common trends p-r and is given by functional of Brownian motions (Dickey-Fuller family); finite-sample corrections or bootstrap may be needed

Asymptotic Result: Estimator of beta, scaled by T, converges to a mixed Gaussian distribution (conditional on common trends); estimators of alpha and short-run parameters are asymptotically Gaussian and asymptotically independent of beta estimator, allowing Wald and LR tests on beta to be chi-square under regularity

Application Claim: The I(1) VAR cointegration framework can test economic hypotheses such as Purchasing Power Parity, present value relations, rational expectations restrictions, and price homogeneity by expressing these hypotheses as linear restrictions on beta and alpha and applying RRR/LR tests

Extension Claim: The VAR likelihood approach extends to richer nonstationary settings including rational expectations in VARs, I(2) models with parametrizations for level and difference cointegration, seasonal and explosive roots, and nonlinear cointegration, though asymptotics and inference become more complex

Method and Result for I(2): When reduced rank of alpha_perp' Gamma beta_perp indicates I(2) behavior, parametrizations yield models where second differences are driven by alpha times (beta' x_{t-1} + psi' Delta x_{t-1}) and allow multicointegration and specialized likelihood inference involving integrated Brownian motions

Limitation and Future Work: Practical issues include sensitivity to model misspecification (autocorrelation, parameter breaks, outliers), limited sample lengths in economics requiring small-sample corrections or bootstrap, and the need for further development of nonlinear cointegration theory and economic theory consistent with nonstationary empirical findings
